solution.text:
The amount of oranges purchased by Raghav = \(_{j}_\frac 12\) kg = \( \frac {(2 \times _{j}_) + 1}{2}\) kg = \( \frac {_{{(2*j)+1}}_}{2} \) kg.
The amount of oranges purchased by Ijaz = \(_{k}_\frac 34\) kg = \( \frac {(4 \times _{k}_) + 3}{4} \) kg = \( \frac {_{{(4*k)+3}}_}{4} \) kg.
We now find the LCM of the denominators of the 2 fractions, i.e. 2 and 4.
LCM of 2 and 4 = 4.
Let us now write the fractions in such a way that they both have the same denominator, i.e. 4, so that we can add them.
\( \Rightarrow \) Amount of oranges purchased by Raghav = \( \frac {_{{(2*j)+1}}_}{2} \times \frac {2}{2} = \frac {_{{((2*j)+1)*2}}_}{4} \) kg
\( \Rightarrow \) Amount of oranges purchased by Ijaz =\( \frac {_{{(4*k)+3}}_}{4} \times \frac 11 = \frac {_{{(4*k)+3}}_}{4} \) kg
Therefore, total quantity of oranges purchased = \( \frac {_{{((2*j)+1)*2}}_}{4} kg + \frac {_{{(4*k)+3}}_}{4} kg \)
= \( \frac { _{{(2*((2*j)+1)) + ((4*k)+3)}}_}{4} \) kg

content.text: Raghav and Ijaz purchased \(_{j}_\frac 12\) kg and \(_{k}_\frac 34\) kg of oranges respectively. How many kilos did they purchase together?
